Review Synthesis of H2O2 and high-value chemicals by covalent organic framework-based photocatalysts Gaoxiong Liu a Rundong Chen a Bingquan Xia a * Zhen Wu b Shantang Liu a * Amin Talebian-Kiakalaieh c Jingrun Ran c * a Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering Process of Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Wuhan Institute of Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei, China Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering Process of Ministry of Education School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering Wuhan Institute of Technology Wuhan Hubei 430074 China Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering Process of Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Wuhan Institute of Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei, China b Department of Chemical Engineering, Ordos Institute of Technology, Ordos 017000, Inner Mongolia, China Department of Chemical Engineering Ordos Institute of Technology Ordos Inner Mongolia 017000 China Department of Chemical Engineering, Ordos Institute of Technology, Ordos 017000, Inner Mongolia, China c School of Chemical Engineering, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, SA 5005, Australia School of Chemical Engineering University of Adelaide Adelaide SA 5005 Australia School of Chemical Engineering, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, SA 5005, Australia * Corresponding author. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is a versatile and environmentally friendly oxidizer widely used in diverse fields. The solar-driven photocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction generates H2O2 from air and water, avoiding undesirable byproducts. This green and pollution-free route is applicable to various domains. Although extensive research covers covalent organic framework (COF)-based photocatalysts for H2O2, little attention has been paid to systems that generate high-value chemicals in the presence of scavengers. To address this gap, we systematically discuss the simultaneous photocatalytic generation of H2O2 and valuable chemicals. We emphasize the pathways for H2O2 generation using COF-based photocatalysts and highlight the role of sacrificial agents. Novel synthetic methodologies and modification strategies for enhancing the photocatalytic yield are presented. Our work aims to strengthen the identification and discussion of the challenges faced by photocatalysts in this field. This study aims to inspire further investigations and innovations in COF-based photocatalysis for sustainable and value-added chemical synthesis by presenting a holistic view. Graphical Abstract Unveiling the secrets in photocatalytic hydrogen peroxide production unlocks the potential of COF-based photocatalysts for photocatalytic production of hydrogen peroxide and value-added chemicals. Keywords Covalent organic framework Photocatalyst H2O2 generation High-value chemical Design strategy 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is a multifunctional green oxidizer [1] that is considered an environmentally friendly substitute for hydrogen (H2) in various applications including medical disinfection, wastewater treatment, chemical synthesis, rocket fuel, electronic device cleaning, and battery energy storage [2–4]. As the demand for H2O2 grows with its widespread use, a pressing need exists for green economic technologies to meet this requirement. The traditional industrial route for H2O2 evolution is the anthraquinone oxidation (AO) [5]. Although mature, this process is characterized by high energy consumption, explosion risk, high cost, and the emission of toxic gases, leading to significant environmental pollution [6]. In contrast, photocatalytic H2O2 production using solar energy, air, and water involves only hydrogen and oxygen and produces no byproducts. This method is green, pollution-free, sustainable, and serves as a safe alternative to the environmentally unfriendly AO process [7–10]. This clean artificial photosynthesis has become a viable technology. Currently, various inorganic photocatalysts, including titanium dioxide (TiO2) [8,10,11], bismuth vanadate (BiVO4) [1], zinc oxide (ZnO) [12–16], and cadmium sulfide (CdS) [17,18] are utilized for photocatalytic H2O2 evolution. However, their limited light absorption range and low selectivity render them unsuitable for this reaction. In contrast, organic semiconductors, such as graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) [9,19–22], resorcinol formaldehyde (RFs) [23], linear conjugated polymers [24], coupled mesoporous polymers [25], and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [26], with tunable light absorption ranges and high electron selectivities, have gained increasing attention. These materials offer tunable energy bands, broad light absorption, and high photocatalytic efficiencies, thereby overcoming the shortcomings of their inorganic counterparts. Covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) [26] represent a novel class of nitrogen-rich porous COFs [27]. Constructed from primary triazine units, these frameworks exhibit a broad spectral response, excellent photogenerated carrier separation and transfer, ordered pores, diverse structures, a large specific surface area, and high stability [28]. In 2020, Voort et al. [29] introduced a COF-based photocatalyst for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) toward H2O2 production. Through rational structural predesign, active sites such as pyridine [30], benzothiazole units [31], bipyridine [32], cyano groups [33], thiophene [34], and nitrogen cations [35] have been introduced into the COF framework, adjusting the ORR pathway to accelerate H2O2 formation and evolution. Notably, external sacrificial agents also enhance the performance and stability of COF-based photocatalysts. In a photocatalytic system, electron donors are added as hole scavengers to capture photogenerated holes, thereby boosting H2O2 production [36]. Various hole scavengers such as methanol, ethanol, furfuryl alcohol (FFA), and benzyl alcohol (BA) are commonly employed to increase the H2O2 yield [37]. Organic chemicals with high added value have been obtained by oxidizing organic hole scavengers with photogenerated holes. For example, methanol, a hole scavenger, can be oxidized by photogenerated holes to produce formaldehyde and formic acid [38]. Intermediate products such as alkoxy radicals resulting from hole scavenger oxidation are reducible and can participate in the ORR half-reaction, indirectly promoting the reduction half-reaction. This innovative approach not only extracts valuable chemicals induced by photogenerated holes but also suppresses competition from the 4e− water oxidation reaction (WOR), thus increasing the H2O2 yield [39]. Consequently, the development of efficient dual-functional photocatalysts capable of simultaneously generating H2O2 and value-added chemicals holds great promise. As depicted in Fig. 1 , methods such as single-atom growth, heterojunction construction, active site regulation, and microenvironment control have proven to be effective for the successful synthesis of dual-functional photocatalysts for generating H2O2 and value-added chemicals. Several studies have explored H2O2 production using COFs. However, a gap in the literature exists regarding reports that specifically focus on photocatalysis to produce both H2O2 and high-value chemicals. This review aims to comprehensively address this issue. We systematically examine various ORR and WOR pathways involved in the synthesis of H2O2. This review also elucidates the intricate mechanisms underlying the oxidation of organic sacrificial agents in the context of the application of COFs in photocatalysis. Advanced synthetic methodologies related to COF-based photocatalytic materials are also included. Subsequent discussion explores strategies to enhance the production of both H2O2 and high-value chemicals within the COF framework. Finally, we present new perspectives on the challenges and advancements inherent to COF-based photocatalysts. By providing nuanced insights, this review aims to drive discussions on improving the overall photocatalytic performance of such frameworks. 2 Mechanism of photocatalytic H2O2 production with COFs and the influence of sacrificial agents Over the years, photocatalysis has expanded into diverse fields involving three pivotal steps on the catalyst surface: light absorption, migration/separation of photogenerated charge carriers, and oxidation-reduction reactions [40]. When the energy of the incident photons is equal to or greater than the bandgap (E g) of the catalyst, the photoreactive semiconductor absorbs the photon energy, exciting electron transitions to the conduction band (CB) stemming from the valence band (VB) and creating electron-hole (e–-h+) pairs [41–44]. The separated charges subsequently migrate to the semiconductor surface, where they drive reactions through interfacial charge transfer [45]. For organic semiconductors, the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) are equivalent to the VB and CB in inorganic semiconductors. Exploring photocatalytic H2O2 production offers insights into the impact of the binding chemistry on the performance, which involves WOR and ORR pathways [42,43], as outlined in Fig. 2 . Different binding modes correspond to different photocatalytic performances. In the ORR binding mode, the CB bottom should be more negative than −0.33 V vs. NHE. ORR production of H2O2 can proceed via direct and/or indirect pathways [44]. The direct 2e– ORR pathway predominantly generates H2O2 through the synergistic reduction of 2e– and two protons. The indirect two-step 1e– ORR generates unstable intermediate products (•O2 –), which may react with other substances in the solution, thus affecting the photocatalytic performance. Thermodynamically, the direct double-electron ORR route is favored because it requires a lower reduction potential of 0.68 V for the CB level. However, kinetically, the two-step 1e− ORR pathway is favored because of its more negative CB position (below −0.33 V vs. NHE) for the reduction potential [46]. COF-based photocatalysts distinguished by their high H2O2 selectivity can be tuned to enhance dual-channel H2O2 production, although the WOR adjustment remains challenging. Common strategies involve employing low-potential oxidation electron donors, such as alcohols [37,47], as sacrificial agents to quench photogenerated holes, aiding in production without external energy inputs. These sacrificial agents not only prevent charge recombination but are also transformed into valuable chemicals, highlighting the importance of understanding these mechanisms for photocatalytic applications. 2.1 The photocatalytic one-step 2e− ORR toward H2O2 production COF-based photocatalysts achieve H2O2 production through a cooperative 2e– ORR pathway. The generation of •O2 – through the 1e– ORR competes with the two-step 2e– ORR process, which inevitably inhibits the photocatalytic production of H2O2. Moreover, the highly oxidizing •O2 – intermediate can damage photocatalysts during the photocatalytic process, thereby restricting their practical applications. Therefore, the direct one-step 2e– pathway of the ORR is of paramount importance for the in situ production of H2O2 with high efficiency and selectivity. Mou et al. [48] successfully synthesized COFs linked by thiazole, imidazole, and oxazole groups. The results showed that thiazole bonds were more conducive for the formation of *O2 intermediates compared to oxazole and imidazole bonds. COFs produce H2O2 through the 2e– ORR pathway, and OZ-COF with oxazole links and IZ-COF with imidazole links may undergo a 4e– WOR; however, this is primarily a one-step 2e– process. The one-step 2e– route has lower kinetic requirements than the two-step 1e– process, which requires a lower catalyst bandgap and energy band structure. The process can occur when the conduction band potential (E CB) is lower than 0.68 V vs. NHE, providing a thermal advantage. Liu et al. [49] experimentally demonstrated that highly electronegative aldehydes might act as absorption sites for H+/O2 in the 2e– ORR, thus enhancing the adsorption performance of Bpy-TAPT and consequently improving H2O2 production via the 2e– ORR. According to the Mott-Schottky diagram, the E CB values of Bpy-TAPB, Bpy-TAPT, and TAPT-CN are –0.60, –0.67, and –0.63 V vs. NHE, respectively. Therefore, energy band structures of these three COFs were sufficient to reduce O2 to ·O2 – and oxidize water to O2. Luo et al. [50] introduced sulfone units onto a COF, as illustrated in Fig. 3 . Their experiments revealed several significant effects. First, the introduction of sulfone units enhanced the separation of photogenerated e–-h+ pairs. Second, the introduction of these units modified the O2 adsorption configuration, increasing the adsorption affinity and improving the protonation abilities of the COFs. These changes collectively improved the photocatalytic performance of the 2e– ORR for H2O2 production in pure water. Furthermore, the incorporation of sulfone groups endowed the FS-COFs with a Yeager-type oxygen adsorption configuration. From a thermodynamic perspective, Pauling-type C-COFs are prone to generate *OOH (O2 + H+ + e– → *OOH), which can then capture protons and electrons to form H2O2 (*OOH + H+ + e– → H2O2). In contrast, due to the sulfone groups in FS-COFs, the two-step 1e– ORR transforms into a direct one-step 2e– ORR (O2 + 2H+ + 2e– → H2O2) when considering the overall reaction mechanism. 2.2 Photocatalytic two-step 1e– ORR to produce H2O2 Soluble O2 undergoes a 1e– conversion and transforms into superoxide radicals (•O2 –), which further react with H+ to form *OOH radicals. Eventually, the *OOH radicals combine with electrons and protons to produce H2O2. The generation of H2O2 via the COF-assisted ORR follows an indirect 1e– transfer ORR pathway. ORR pathways with 1e− are kinetically more favorable than 2e– ORR pathways. The key prerequisite for photocatalytic H2O2 production on the catalyst surface is that it meets the ORR potential criteria. Specifically, when the CB potential is more negative than −0.33 V vs. NHE, an indirect 2e− ORR occurs via two-step 1e− reduction pathways. Changes in the bandgap and intermediate energy levels can lead to a shift from indirect to direct 2e− ORR pathways. Cheng et al. [31] analyzed the reaction pathway using electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and theoretical calculations. They found that •O2 – and 1O2 act as active oxygen species in the photocatalytic H2O2 production process. Photogenerated electrons are transferred along the π-conjugated chain to the photocatalyst surface, reducing O2 to •O2 –. A portion of the holes oxidize water to generate O2 and H+, while the remaining holes react with •O2 – to form 1O2. The H2O2 production occurs through two pathways simultaneously: (1) photoinduced two-step 1e− reduction of O2 (O2 → •O2 − → H2O2) and (2) 1e− reduction of O2, followed by generation and conversion of 1O2 (O2 → •O2 − → 1O2 → H2O2). 1O2 enhances O2 reduction selectivity toward H2O2, improves charge carrier separation, and reduces the barrier to H2O2 production. The introduction of certain heteroatoms influences the energy barriers of the two-step 1e− reaction, thereby facilitating the reaction pathway. Zhou et al. [30] increased the number of obscure ORR active sites in a TAPTPDA-COF by introducing pyridine-based N atoms into the benzene ring. The coordination of pyridine-N to the N atom of the imine bond mitigates the energy barriers involved in O2 adsorption and activation. DFT calculations revealed the continuing two-step 1e– reduction pathway of O2 between the imine-N and pyridine-N. As shown in Fig. 4 , while the N atoms within the pyridine unit and imine bond undergo electron loss, O2 and •OOH are the electron recipients. The synergy between the pyridine-N and imine-N atoms provides a viable site for O2 adsorption and activation, favoring the introduction of the pyridine unit and a two-step 1e– ORR route. 2.3 Photocatalytic H2O2 production via a dual-channel pathway The full photoproduction of H2O2 involves two pathways: the ORR and WOR. Most reported photocatalysts are better suited for H2O2 production via the ORR. However, the most ideal and energy-efficient pathway is to achieve simultaneous H2O2 photoproduction via both the WOR and ORR, thus maximizing energy utilization. Yue et al. [34] constructed two novel thiophene-based COFs (TT-COF and TD-COF) and used them as photocatalysts to produce H2O2 via the ORR and WOR pathways. Gas chromatography and rotary ring disk electrode (RRDE) test results excluded the 4e– WOR pathway. The RRDE demonstrated H2O2 generation through both the 2e– ORR and 2e– WOR mechanisms. The 2e– WOR and ORR can generate H2O2; however, because of the higher redox potential required for 2e– reactions than for 4e− reactions, the selectivity of 2e– reactions is relatively low, hindering large-scale H2O2 production. Moreover, H2O2 generation can also be achieved through the oxidation of water (2H2O + 2h+ → H2O2 + 2H+). To explore porous crystalline materials for potential large-scale H2O2 production in industry, Chang et al. [51] constructed redox molecular junctions using COFs with photothermal absorption and integrated redox centers through oriented design, which could simultaneously complete the WOR and ORR processes and significantly promote charge transfer. The results confirmed that the TTF-BT-COF produced H2O2 via a 2e–-transfer process, concurrently utilizing both the WOR and ORR. The proposed mechanism entails the WOR and ORR (i.e., *OOH and *OH) synergistically coupling different reaction intermediates that are simultaneously generated. Integration of the TTF component was found to reduce the overall energy barrier of the system. Moreover, through computational analysis, the sulfur sites were confirmed (Fig. 5 ) to adsorb key intermediates (*OH and *OOH), thereby promoting the ORR and WOR processes. Specifically, the ORR pathway involves the conversion of O2 to the *OOH intermediate, which subsequently binds to a proton in the WOR to generate H2O2 [52]. Thereby, the ORR reaction consumes the protons produced by the WOR, while the latter involves the oxidation of H2O to •OH radicals. The coupling of two ·OH radicals leads to further H2O2 formation. Consequently, the concurrent ORR and WOR pathways constitute dual channels for balancing charge within the catalytic system. 2.4 Impact of sacrificial agents on H2O2 production Owing to thermodynamic challenges, achieving a 2e– WOR (1.76 V) is difficult. Sacrificial agents are commonly used to effectively utilize the WOR pathway. Alcohol sacrificial agents are widely used because they can serve as both electron and proton donors. The photogenerated holes oxidize alcohols, producing aldehydes and protons. Simultaneously, the electrons facilitate the 2e– reduction of oxygen, leading to the production of H2O2. By using biomass furfuryl alcohol (FFA) as a sacrificial agent, photocatalytic H2O2 production can also produce high-value-added products. A study conducted by Chang et al. [37] investigated the photocatalytic production of H2O2 and oxidation of FFA, which resulted in the formation of furoic acid (FA), as shown in Fig. 6 . The efficiency of FA production from Cu3-BT-COF reached 575 mmol L−1 g−1. Meanwhile, the yield of H2O2 reached 187000 μmol L−1 g−1. H2O2 is mainly produced via the ORR reaction pathway, but oxygen isotope experiments indicated that a small amount of H2O2 was produced by the WOR. Competition exists between the WOR and photo-oxidation of FFA, wherein FFA photo-oxidation plays a key role in the half-reaction. The furfuryl alcohol oxygen reduction (FOR) reaction pathway is as follows (*R-CH2OH → *R-CH2O → *R-CHO → *R-C(OH)2 → *R-COOH → R-COOH, * indicates the presence of the catalytic site): the initial protonation of the α-hydrogen on FFA (*R-CH-OH-H+ → *R-CH2O), followed by the formation of *R-CHO, spontaneous transformation of *R-CHO to *R-C(OH)2, and further oxidation of the adsorbed *R-C(OH)2 intermediate to *R-COOH. The final step involves the desorption of *R-COOH, which contributes to the formation of FA. Although adding a sacrificial agent improves the photocatalytic performance, isolating H2O2 from the aqueous system is challenging because of the presence of a water-soluble alcohol. If not removed, this water-soluble alcohol will consume the produced H2O2, and complete removal increases production costs. Benzyl alcohol (BA), which is characterized by its oily and aromatic properties, was employed as a sacrificial agent in the photocatalytic production of H2O2 in water to form a liquid (water)-liquid (organic)-gas-solid multiple-phase system [47]. These reactions occurred around the catalyst surface in the organic phase, and the generated H2O2 dissolved in the aqueous phase. The substance can be extracted and separated from oil and/or water, resulting in an eco-friendly, simple, and rapid method for H2O2 production. This approach also maximizes the overall energy-utilization efficiency. Das et al. [36] synthesized COFs prepared by multi-component Povarov reactions (PMCR-1) that exhibited high activity for photocatalytic H2O2 production and selective photocatalytic oxidation. When BA was added as a sacrificial agent, the yield of H2O2 increased significantly, and BA was selectively oxidized to the corresponding aldehyde. Benzylamines and thiols were selected to study the multifunctionality of photocatalytic systems. Benzylamines (PhCH=NH) were photocatalytically generated from benzyl alcohol as a sacrificial agent, and N-benzyl-1-phenylformamide was produced. Notably, with sunlight as the light source, the low concentration of benzylamine (0.01:1) in water resulted in an H2O2 yield of 4529 μmol g−1 h−1 after 1 h under an oxygen atmosphere. Similarly, two-phase systems were produced in water with thioethers (0.1:1), but the H2O2 yield was lower than that of BA or benzylamine (905 μmol g−1 h−1). The aerobic oxidation of molecular compounds has led to the development of valuable pharmaceutical products. 3 Synthetic strategies for COF-based photocatalysts In recent years, COF materials have gained significant attention as a new class of crystalline porous materials with notable advancements in their synthetic strategies. A comprehensive summary of these strategies will contribute to the widespread application of COFs in various fields. The main fabrication strategies for COFs include electrostatic self-assembly, in situ synthesis, gas-phase-assisted synthesis, pore partitioning, and interface polymerization, as shown in Fig. 7 . These strategies enable the development of COF-based photocatalytic materials that not only facilitate heterojunction construction but also support film formation. Additionally, they allow for the regulation of COF pore sizes, thereby increasing the number of active sites. These materials play a critical role in the photocatalytic production of H2O2 and valuable chemical products. 3.1 Electrostatic self-assembly Electrostatic self-assembly is a widely adopted method for synthesizing COF materials that uses electrostatic interactions to achieve an orderly assembly. Lin et al. [53] and Zhang et al. [38] utilized this straightforward approach to form heterostructures on COF surfaces, thereby enhancing the spatial separation of photogenerated carriers and minimizing recombination at defect sites. Zhou et al. [54] prepared atomically dispersed bimetallic photocatalysts, LaNi-Phen/COF-5, via ligand-assisted electrostatic self-assembly utilizing phenanthroline ligands. This innovative method combines optical and catalytic centers to foster high photothermal absorption and effective charge separation. LaNi-Phen/COF-5 exhibits the benefits of single-atom metals, bimetallic synergies, and COF customizability, delivering robust light absorption, exceptional catalytic performance, and selective product targeting. This electrostatic method efficiently couples molecules to form heterostructures, boosting carrier transfer rates, reducing photocorrosion, and improving photocatalyst stability. 3.2 In situ synthetic strategy The in situ synthetic strategy harnesses reaction conditions such as heat and pressure to grow COF materials, enabling precise control over their purity and structure. Li et al. [55] introduced a one-pot, multi-component, in situ technique to synthesize highly crystalline and porous COFs via Strecker and Povarov reactions under solvothermal conditions. This approach parallels post-synthetic modifications and offers a new pathway for complicated COF synthesis. Zhu et al. [56] introduced a one-pot, multi-component, in situ technique to synthesize highly crystalline and porous COFs via Strecker and Povarov reactions under solvothermal conditions. This approach parallels post-synthetic modifications and offers a new pathway for difficult COF syntheses. In situ synthesized COFs feature ample negative groups and uniform nanopores, showing superior electrochemical capabilities and offering a novel design approach for artificial photosynthetic systems [57,58]. 3.3 Steam-assisted process Steam-assisted synthesis employing gas-phase reactions, such as metal-organic compound vapor deposition (MOCVD) and chemical vapor deposition (CVD), yields COF materials with high atom utilization and gentle conditions. Wang et al. [59] synthesized CuPc-AQ-COF films via vapor assistance, achieving high conductivity and hole mobility owing to the smart molecular design. These films, with their smooth surface and unaffected by substrate, benefit from multilayer π-π stacking for improved charge transfer. This method is key for producing thin COF films with enhanced electrical conductivity, as demonstrated by Mei et al. [60] and Yue et al. [61]. 3.4 Pore partitioning method Pore partitioning creates COFs with distinct pore structures as well as fine-tuned molecular transport and catalytic properties. Achieved through template or surfactant-assisted synthesis, this strategy involves inserting a symmetrically compatible building block into an existing framework and subdividing a large pore into smaller ones. Xu et al. [62] adopted this synthetic strategy for two-dimensional COFs to achieve precise pore characteristic control. Jing et al. [63] used a “pre-nucleation and sluggish growth” approach for the synthesis of oriented mesopore COF films, immobilizing functional components and coordinating with Cu ions for effective pore partitioning. 3.5 Interfacial polymerization method Interfacial polymerization, which involves dissolving monomers in distinct solvents for COF synthesis, capitalizes on solvent polarity differences to arrange the molecules in an orderly manner [64,65]. This approach, exemplified by Zhao et al.’s triphenylamine-based COF composite films, is effective for producing structurally ordered, high-performance COF films [66]. The OT-IP process, which benefits from electrochemical and migration synergies, hastens crystallization. Large-area, ultrathin 2D COF membranes with precise control over angstrom-scale pore size were synthesized by Shevate et al. [67], offering insights into the design and optimization of COF membranes for organic solvent molecular separation. 4 COF modification to increase H2O2 and high-value chemical production 4.1 Single atom growth Single-atom catalysts (SACs) disperse metal atoms to specific locations within the pores of a COF, achieving precise control of the COF catalytic active center [68]. SACs exhibit the combined characteristics of “isolated active sites” typically found in homogeneous catalysts and the “stable and easily divided” nature of heterogeneous catalysts. Furthermore, SACs achieve the maximum utilization of metal atoms, ensuring 100% atomic efficiency. Liu et al. [69] synthesized COF-366-M derivatives (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) with high structural unity loaded with different 3d transition metals using porphyrin-containing COFs. The metal sites of COF-366-Co have a higher turnover frequency for H2O2 than the metal sites of other catalysts and also have a high selectivity for H2O2 synthesis. Ren et al. [70] developed a g-C3N4 catalyst with atomically dispersed Mn for direct H2O2 production from seawater. The Mn-based catalyst with unsaturated Mn-N x sites atomically dispersed on aromatic amine-substituted g-C3N4 exhibited excellent catalytic activity and stability. The introduction of aromatic amines shortened the bandgap and improved light absorption. At the Mn-N x sites, O2 adsorption and activation were stimulated, the separation of photogenerated e–-h+ pairs was aided, and their recombination was inhibited, thus achieving excellent catalytic activity. The proposed synthetic approach offers an alternative to conventional techniques for the production of metal-g-C3N4 catalysts. These catalysts exhibit excellent atomic dispersion and contain coordinatively unsaturated metal-N x sites derived from non-noble transition metals. This method is expected to have wide application in various (photo)electrocatalytic reactions and organic transformations. Liu et al. [71] introduced a novel strategy for synthesizing fluorinated COFs to limit Pd metal-isolated clusters (ICs), thereby significantly improving the photocatalytic activity and stability of H2O2 production (Fig. 8 ). Strongly electronegative fluorine enhances the interaction with the metal support, improving the stability of single-atom COFs. Pd metal clusters can accelerate the photocatalytic activity of 1e– ORRs to produce H2O2. The TAPT-TFPA COFs@Pd ICs photocatalyst optimized to its best performance yields a stable output of H2O2 reaching 2143 μmol h−1 g−1. 4.2 Heterojunction construction Single-component inorganic catalysts and bare COFs face challenges related to low carrier recombination and low separation efficiency in photocatalytic H2O2 production. The construction of heterojunctions can significantly enhance photocatalytic activity and e–-h+ separation, compensating for the defects of single catalysts [72–77]. COFs offer tunable energy bands, ordered porosity, and high conjugation, which are unique advantages complementing inorganic photocatalysts. The integration of COFs and other semiconductor photocatalysts forms heterojunctions, which improve the overall photocatalytic performance by retaining the structural characteristics of both materials [78]. Numerous studies have reported the photocatalytic performance of COF-based composites with inorganic nanomaterials, such as WO3/COF [79], TiO2/COF [80], ZnO/COF [38], and BiOBr/COF [81], through appropriately designing heterojunctions. The built-in electric fields in these composites facilitate charge carrier separation and transfer at the interfaces [82]. For example, Zhang et al. [38] prepared an S-scheme heterojunction ZnO/COF (TpPa-Cl) using a simple electrostatic self-assembly method. Upon irradiation with sunlight, the optimal composite material demonstrates a maximum H2O2 evolution rate of 2443 μmol g−1 h−1, which is 3.3 times and 8.7 times higher than those of raw zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles and TpPa-Cl, respectively. Subsequently, Yang et al. [79] proposed a Z-type heterojunction WO3/Tp-TAPB, which changed the charge transfer pathways, enhanced the built-in electric fields in the two single components, and synergistically utilized the ultrathin structure of the COF, resulting in significantly improved e–-h+ pair separation and utilization efficiency while retaining the strong oxidative and reductive capabilities of WO3 and Tp-TAPB. In pure water, the photocatalytic activity of WO3/Tp-TAPB reached 1488.4 μmol g−1 h−1, which is 72.3 and 2.8 times higher than those of pure WO3 and Tp-TAPB, respectively. With the emergence of COF-based heterojunctions, other approaches have shown significant development potential. Yang et al. [80] synthesized a covalent organic framework (BTTA) on titanium dioxide nanofibers via Schiff base condensation and in situ growth. The synthesized TiO2/BTTA composites exhibited large interfaces and short carrier migration distances (Fig. 9 ) along with a H2O2 production rate of 740 μmol g−1 h−1. In situ x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and electron spin resonance (ESR) confirmed that the S-scheme facilitates charge carrier transfer, with the added benefit of spatially isolating photogenerated carriers that exhibit strong redox potential. Based on a series of characterizations, we propose a complete reaction mechanism: furfuryl alcohol is subject to oxidation by holes, transforming into furoic acid, and the reduction of O2 and electrons results in the formation of H2O2 (Fig. 9). 4.3 Active site regulation The precise regulation of active sites and adjustment of electronic structures play crucial roles in the rational design of photocatalysts for achieving H2O2 production. Through molecular design, COF-based photocatalysts can be finely tuned to achieve high activity and selectivity in producing H2O2 from water and oxygen, involving both the ORR and WOR. Chen et al. [83] designed COF-based photocatalysts (HEP-TAPA-COF and HEP-TAPB-COF) to incorporate spatially isolated redox centers at the molecular level, enabling the efficient synthesis of H2O2. Among them, HEP-TAPT-COF stands out by featuring both the s-heptazine ring and triazine portion as active sites for the ORR (Fig. 10(a) ), surpassing the performance of HEP-TAPB-COF, which relies solely on the s-heptazine ring for the ORR. Both HEP-TAPB-COF and HEP-TAPT-COF facilitated a 4e– WOR within their benzene groups. This study emphasized the importance of spatially separated redox centers for effective charge separation and improved photocatalytic H2O2 synthesis. Consequently, HEP-TAPT-COF, with dual O2 reduction centers, demonstrated superior performance in photocatalytic H2O2 production (87.50 μmol g−1 h−1) and higher solar-to-chemical energy efficiency (0.65%). Photocatalytic performance can be improved by selecting different building blocks in COFs, adjusting the charge density difference between the active sites and O2, and designing dual active sites. Chang et al. [51] synthesized TTF-BT-COF, which combined tetrathiafulvalene (photocatalytic oxidation sites) and benzothiazole (photocatalytic reduction sites) through covalent coupling. This covalent connection forms an oxidoreductive junction that exhibits visible light absorption, efficient electrostatic hole separation, and suitable photocatalytic redox abilities. Consequently, efficient electron transfer from BT to TTF occurs under visible light, enabling simultaneous ORR and WOR. Remarkably, TTF-BT-COF achieved a record-breaking H2O2 production rate of approximately 276000 μmol g−1 h−1 without the need for sacrificial agents. This rate was approximately ten times higher than that of a single linker or physical mixture. Additionally, the COF demonstrated the capability to easily generate high-concentration H2O2 in long-term batch experiments, showcasing its feasibility for practical applications. DFT theory calculations confirmed that redox molecular junctions facilitate charge transfer and significantly lower the energy barriers of the WOR and ORR, leading to improved performance. Hao et al. [35] successfully created highly active nitrogen cation sites on 1,10-phenanthroline-5,6-dione-based COFs through photodriven quasi-topological transformations (Fig. 10(b)). These sites play a crucial role in the 2e– O2 photoreduction process, enabling the synthesis of H2O2. The exposed nitrogen cation sites possess photostimulated Lewis acidity, which serves multiple functions, including driving electron transfer, adjusting the intrinsic charge distribution, and achieving sustained and stable charge separation. Additionally, they enhance visible light absorption and provide numerous active sites for O2 adsorption. The study demonstrated that the optimal catalyst achieved an H2O2 yield of up to 11965 μmol g−1 h−1 under visible light irradiation, along with an apparent quantum efficiency of 12.9% at 400 nm. These results surpassed those of most previously reported COF photocatalysts. Compounds such as pyrene [47], diarylamines [29], pyridines [30], diacetylenes [84], and sulfones [50] have been identified as favorable active sites for photocatalytic H2O2 production. Specifically, the presence of pyridine and diacetylene structures enables water oxidation to generate H2O2, whereas the introduction of sulfone units facilitates the transition from a two-step ORR to a one-step ORR during H2O2 production. Adjusting the electronic properties of the active center to achieve a balance between the oxygen adsorption capacity and reactivity for the 2e– ORR is crucial during the photoelectrocatalytic synthesis of H2O2. 4.4 Microenvironment control During photocatalytic H2O2 production, the combination of O2 and electrons generates highly reactive superoxide radicals (•O2 –). These radicals effectively clear electrons and suppress e–-h+ recombination on the catalyst surface, enabling the formation of a gas-liquid-solid three-phase catalytic system in water. This system allows airborne oxygen to directly contact the solid catalyst in the liquid phase, thereby facilitating the ORR. Therefore, the limitations of a low dissolved oxygen content and slow transport velocity in water, which can hinder the ability of the ORR to clear e–, can be overcome. In traditional liquid-solid two-phase systems, catalysts are more hydrophilic and rely on the solubility and diffusion rate of O2 in water. However, this hydrophilicity can lead to the decomposition of the H2O2 produced due to the hydrophilicity of the catalyst. Introducing a gas phase directly into the catalyst helps to mitigate this issue, enabling the conversion of oxygen into high concentrations of H2O2. Designing a gas-liquid-solid three-phase interfacial microenvironment is a promising approach for enhancing photocatalytic performance. Yue et al. [34] introduced two novel thiophene-based COFs, namely TD-COF and TT-COF, with distinct hydrophilic and hydrophobic properties. TD-COF exhibited super hydrophilicity with a water contact angle of 124.4°. In the absence of a sacrificial agent, super hydrophilicity can accelerate the kinetics of the WOR and enhance the overall photocatalytic production of H2O2. However, the presence of sacrificial agents in the reaction, combined with hydrophilicity, can accelerate the decomposition of H2O2 and affect the photocatalytic performance. Sun et al. [47] employed a multiphase reaction system consisting of a liquid (water)-liquid(organic)-gas-solid phase as hole scavengers. Owing to the hydrophobic nature of the COFs, they were dispersed in the benzyl alcohol phase, facilitating the rapid diffusion of the generated H2O2 into the water layer. The active sites of the COFs remained in the benzyl alcohol phase, avoiding direct contact with the catalyst and enabling an increase in the H2O2 concentration in the water phase. The oxidation of BA in the organic phase produced benzaldehyde, a high-value-added chemical. This whole-reaction photocatalysis, utilizing the ORR pathway for H2O2 reduction and WOR pathway for oxidizing sacrificial agents to produce valuable chemicals, promotes rapid charge transfer and facilitates both the ORR and WOR channels. In the absence of a sacrificial agent, photocatalytic reactions enhance the hydrophobicity and reduce the contact between the catalyst and water phase. Chen et al. [85] developed a gas-liquid-solid three-phase interface using melamine foam to facilitate oxygen transport (Fig. 11 ). Their experiments demonstrated the coexistence of the Wenzel-Cassie state at the hydrophobic interface, creating enclosed tubular spaces that efficiently captured gases in water. The combination of a superhydrophobic surface and high porosity significantly enhanced the gas diffusion capacity and increased the oxygen concentration in the reaction system. The tubular design ensured thorough light absorption and effectively inhibited the decomposition of H2O2, leading to a significant improvement in the overall reaction activity. The construction of a three-phase system begins by accelerating the rapid diffusion of oxygen from air to the reaction interface. Maximizing the utilization of oxygen at the three-phase reaction interface is the key to unlocking the potential of the three-phase system. Yan et al. [86] developed a three-phase photocatalytic system that addressed the challenges related to rapid charge recombination, poor selectivity for 2e– ORRs, and restricted O2 diffusion rates. H2O2 production occurs at the gas-liquid-solid interface. The addition of pyrrole units and cyano groups enhances oxygen molecule activation, improves carrier separation efficiency, and accelerates oxygen transport from the air to the reaction interface. As a result, the H2O2 generation rate in pure water increases ten-fold (2063.21 μmol g−1 h−1) compared to powdered photocatalysts (215.44 μmol g−1 h−1). Although the concentration of dissolved oxygen in water is typically crucial for oxygen activation in the ORR, Li et al. [87] found that TPB-DMTP-COF exhibited higher activity for H2O2 generation under sunlight exposure, despite the reduced oxygen levels in pure water. Furthermore, by immobilizing TPB-DMTP-COF on porous carbon fiber paper, a three-phase reaction interface was established owing to the hydrophobic nature of the polymer semiconductor. In this configuration, the H2O2 generation rate reached 2882 μmol g−1 h−1, which is 15 times higher than that of the corresponding two-phase system. The porous carbon carrier facilitated faster oxygen diffusion to the catalyst, significantly enhancing mass transfer. Additionally, the elevated oxygen concentration at the three-phase interface promoted effective e–-h+ separation, thereby improving the photocatalytic kinetics. 5 Challenges and perspectives The production of H2O2 using solar energy is a secure and sustainable approach. This review examined the mechanisms of H2O2 production using COF-based photocatalysts and the critical role of hole scavengers. These scavengers contribute to the photocatalytic coproduction of H2O2 and high-value chemicals, as shown in Table 1 . The challenges and prospects in this area are shown in Fig. 12 . This review explores novel synthetic methods for COF-based photocatalysts, focusing on modification strategies such as single-atom growth, heterojunction construction, active site regulation, and microenvironment control. These modifications demonstrate the potential of COF-based photocatalysts to enhance photocatalytic H2O2 production and organic transformations. However, the detailed mechanisms of H2O2 production via the ORR and WOR using COF-based photocatalysts remain unclear. Understanding the reaction mechanism in photocatalysis would greatly benefit diverse applications of photocatalysts. Utilizing advanced in situ characterization techniques such as femtosecond transient absorption spectroscopy, ESR spectroscopy, and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy can help reveal the competition between the ORR and WOR. Nonetheless, the use of COF-based photocatalysts for H2O2 production is still in its early stages and requires further research for industrial application. Moreover, the separation and purification of the target products are crucial factors in photocatalytic H2O2 production coupled with the synthesis of valuable chemicals, directly impacting the efficiency and practical applicability. Maximizing the active surface area accessible to the reactants (water and oxygen) is essential for increasing the H2O2 production rate. Effective separation techniques are vital for obtaining high-purity H2O2 and ensuring continuous operation of the photocatalytic system. Progress in catalyst development, reactor design, and separation technology is the key to improving the efficiency, scalability, and sustainability of the process. Future research should focus on practical applications that can accelerate industrial adoption. References 1 T. Liu Z. Pan J.J.M. Vequizo K. Kato B. Wu A. Yamakata K. Katayama B. Chen C. Chu K. Shantang Liu (School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Wuhan Institute of Technology) Professor Shantang Liu completed his Ph.D. in the College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering at Peking University in 2000. Following that, he pursued postdoctoral research at esteemed international institutions, including the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel, Laval University in Canada, and Virginia Commonwealth University in the United States, from 2000 to 2007. In 2007, he joined Wuhan Institute of Technology as a full professor. Professor Liu’s research interests encompass a diverse range of areas, including MEMS gas sensors, catalytic decomposition of pollutants, photothermal catalysis, energy conversion and storage. He has actively collaborated with industry partners to promote the commercialization of research outcomes and has a strong track record of publishing more than 100 peer-reviewed papers. Bingquan Xia (School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Wuhan Institute of Technology) obtained his Ph.D. degree in 2022 from the University of Adelaide in Australia. Following the completion of his doctoral studies, he joined the faculty of the School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering at Wuhan Institute of Technology. His research is centered around the development of novel materials for photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. Specifically, he is particularly interested in the field of photocatalysis, with a focus on the conversion of solar energy into green fuels and valuable chemicals. With a strong dedication to advancing scientific knowledge, he has published 25 peer-reviewed papers.

coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is a versatile and environmentally friendly oxidizer widely used in diverse fields. The solar-driven photocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction generates H2O2 from air and water, avoiding undesirable byproducts. This green and pollution-free route is applicable to various domains. Although extensive research covers covalent organic framework (COF)-based photocatalysts for H2O2, little attention has been paid to systems that generate high-value chemicals in the presence of scavengers. To address this gap, we systematically discuss the simultaneous photocatalytic generation of H2O2 and valuable chemicals. We emphasize the pathways for H2O2 generation using COF-based photocatalysts and highlight the role of sacrificial agents. Novel synthetic methodologies and modification strategies for enhancing the photocatalytic yield are presented. Our work aims to strengthen the identification and discussion of the challenges faced by photocatalysts in this field. This study aims to inspire further investigations and innovations in COF-based photocatalysis for sustainable and value-added chemical synthesis by presenting a holistic view.
